People will take advantage when one's back is turned.

Posts.Title: Groan, groan, Really bad meeting with PS tarry dontworrybehappy

Posts.Content: tarry wrote: He's head of breast plastic surgery in a highly praised cancer center and he was rude, abrupt and mean.  I want a lumpectomy and I don't want a mastectomy, and all he wanted to do was to argue that I should have one, all the while making condescending and dismissive comments in response to anything i had to say.  I really, really didn't need this. It wasn't just me; my quite tough and highly professional husband was shocked by this guy's behavior.  I mean, we are both professionals in science areas, so he didn't have to assume we don't know anything.  I cannot understand why no one can show us any pictures of lumpectomies.  I know I will lose a third of my breast and it is very clear that my BS and my PS think it will look bad, but will I share their judgments?  One person her has sent me a picture of her lumpectomy which took about a fourth of her breast, and I thought it was just fine.  I feel ill at the experience.  And I am so sorry; there are so many brave women on this site; I'm just indulging myself, I suppose.  But I needed a PS who would be an ally, not enemy.  Dx 5/30/2011, IDC, Right, 4cm, Grade 2, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 10:11PM tarry wrote: SpecialK, I realize those are not your figures, but I have to say I'm a bit shocked at what people will say. Please don't think I'm criticizing you for repeating it! We have to share what we hear from official sources. i'm pretty sure that there is no scientific backing for that figure. The World Health Organization has said that breastcancer in the US could be lowered by 34% (i think that was their figured; it might have been 36) by women not being overweight PLUS exerxising more PLUS drinking less, where the official recommendation for "safe" dring is about 1.5 hours of liquor (or equivalent wine or beer) a day. British women are in worse shape, the WHO seems to think, since they could reduce it by 42%. I worry that such statements are highly political and lead us away from thinking about the hormones abundantly polluting our environment, not to speak of other noxious stuff.

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 11:52PM - edited Oct 7, 2011 11:52PM by tarry I just found one response from a CVS 'press release.'. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends flu shots for people at high risk for complications from influenza, adults ages 50 and older, those with respiratory or chronic diseases that lower the body's immune system, those with pulmonary or cardiovascular disorders, and those receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy. The flu vaccine is also recommended for women who will be pregnant during influenza season. I don't know if this is correct, though.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 09:58AM tarry wrote: Cancer is a very hard country, and you need to take care of yourself too. Eating healthful foods and getting some exercise are very standard things that can make you more resilient. Anti-depressants can be a huge help. Try to find some time for things you enjoy. Books, music, sewing, painting, dvds, whatever. Bring in some fresh flowers. Try to keep your grooming in good shape. Do small things to give you more of a sense of contro!. Sorting out drawers, etc. Come to this forum to share your story and connect with others. Some ideas ...

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 05:35PM - edited Dec 17, 2011 05:36PM by tarry I finished a four week rad schedule about 4 weeks ago. It was at md anderson in houston. The protocol is still considered experimental in the States, but since they are doing a big study on it, they felt safe in using it on me. The daily dose was stronger, but for some reason, the results on the web suggest it is easier on the skin. I think it was pretty much a breeze, though everyone was quite amazed at how well my skin withstood the rads. I now look fairly tanned in the area that got an extra dosage for the tumor bed with the booster but otherwise it seems fine. My husband thinks it slowed me down, but I didn't have the fatigue I've heard a lot about. 2 weeks after the rads ended, I went on a demanding 3 city lecture tour in England. I've arrived home with a good sense of energy, and no bad experiences traveling, unless you count about 15 hours of British buses and trains bad.
Posts.Title: biopsy Eileenohio DebConway

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2015 05:48PM tarry wrote: my surgery was just over 4 years ago at MD Anderson. They,ll give you first class treatment, but you may feel pressurized to go with their alternative, as opposed to what you really want. I had a several months long disagreement with a number of drs. I wanted a lumpectomy, but they were really insisting I have a masectomy with implants. There's an idea that recovery involves getting as close to your pre-cancer look as possible. That might be what you want and, if so, you'll get the best there is. Otherwise, insist on what makes you feel best, as long as it is medically effective. There is another problem. Once you are through the initial treatment, it can be hard to get to see a doctor. I have't seen one since dec 2011, even though I go for 6 months checkups. You are stuck with nurse practitioners. I ended up going through patient advocacy to get to see a doctor

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 03:46PM - edited Sep 22, 2011 06:22PM by tarry I felt quite suicidal for a while. When I feel my life is now taken over by others, I can get like that. Try to find parts of your life you still can control and work on what they need. At least that's helped me. Cancer is very scary, but you will have more strength than you realize.
